texts.shortText:
Fairly broad-bodied, elongate-oval worm with the dorsal surface completely covered by 15 pairs of large, off-white, overlapping scales, each of which bears a gray centre and a broad, grey, crescent-shaped marginal marking.

Also easily recognized by its habit of living commensally in the burrows of Sand prawns Kraussillichirus kraussi.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to False Bay.

A locally endemic species found only at a few sites in the southwestern Cape and associated mostly with the burrows of sand prawns, within which it lives commensally. Most commonly seen when accidentally discarded on the sand surface by anglers who are collecting sand prawns using a prawnâ€“pump. Little else is known about its biology.
Carnivorous, feeding on small invertebrates buried in the sediment.
Little is known about reproduction in this group, but sexes are separate and it is assumed that eggs and sperm are released directly into the water column, where they develop into planktonic larvae.

Scaleworms are easily recognized as a group due to the flat dorsal scales that cover all, or much, of the body. This species is unusual in that the scales are white and the worm is found on sandy substrata and is associated with sand-prawn burrows (most scaleworms are free-living and the majority live on hard substrata).

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 64).

Day, JH (1953). The polychaet fauna of South Africa. Part 2. Errant species from Cape shores and estuaries. Annals of the Natal Museum, 12(3), 397-441.

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History) , London, Part. 1 Errantia (p. 58).
